elements.content: One of the enticing features of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is the potential to control the chemical and physical nature of the pores through postsynthetic modification. The incorporation of redox active guest molecules inside the pores of the framework represents one strategy toward improving the charge transport properties of MOFs. Herein, we report the vapor-phase redox intercalation of an electroactive organic compound, hydroquinone (H2Q) or benzene-1,4-diol, into the channels of the host [VIVO(bdc)], (bdc =1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) conventionally denoted as MIL-47. The temperatures and especially the atmosphere in which the reactions took place were found to determine the products. In ambient atmosphere, quinhydrone charge-transfer complexes are formed inside the channels. Under anhydrous conditions, the framework itself was functionalized by a radical anion species derived from the pyrolysis of hydroquinone. Both cases are accompanied by the reduction of V4+ to V3+ via single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations. The products were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, infrared spectroscopy, and electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy.

elements.content: Redox active organic compound, hydroquinone or benzene-1,4-diol, is incorporated into the channels of a vanadium-based metal−organic framework, [VIVO(bdc)] (bdc =1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) conventionally denoted as MIL-47. In the presence of air, quinhydrone charge-transfer complexes form inside the channels, whereas under anhydrous vacuum conditions, the framework itself is functionalized by a radical anion species derived from hydroquinone pyrolysis, via single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), assembled from inorganic building units (metal ions or clusters) and organic linkers, have attracted tremendous attention in the past two decades. Due to the design and synthesis flexibility inherent in MOFs, many efforts have been made to use these materials in technological applications in categories such as gas storage, selective molecular adsorption, separations, ion exchange, catalysis, magnetic and photoluminescence responses, optoelectronics, and drug delivery. Some of the hybrid organic–inorganic porous frameworks demonstrate significant structural flexibility in response to changes, in guest concentration, pressure, or temperature with retention of single crystallinity. Examples include the MX(bdc) compounds first reported by Férey et al., which are based on chains of trans corner-sharing MX2O4 (M = V, Cr, Al, Fe, In, Ga, Mn, Sc, and X = O, OH, F) octahedra cross-linked by 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc). The three-dimensional framework that results consists of one-dimensional rhombic channels. The first member of the group [VIII(OH)(bdc)](H2bdc) x , known as MIL-47as, loses the guest acid on heating in air and at the same time the framework V3+ ions are oxidized to V4+ forming [VIVO(bdc)] or MIL-47, without changing the topology of the framework, thus providing the first evidence of chemically induced redox reactions within this system. One particular feature of [VIVO(bdc)], MIL-47, is its lack of affinity for water. As a result, by removing H2bdc guest molecules, the empty framework is obtained which is stable under ambient conditions. A second example of a redox reaction was reported by Férey et al., who investigated the electrochemical reactivity of [FeIII(OH)0.8F0.2(bdc)](H2O) [MIL-53(Fe)] with lithium. Lithium ions can be repeatedly intercalated/deintercalated into/from the channels, accompanied by reduction/oxidation of Fe3+ and Fe2+.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), assembled from inorganic building units (metal ions or clusters) and organic linkers, have attracted tremendous attention in the past two decades. Due to the design and synthesis flexibility inherent in MOFs, many efforts have been made to use these materials in technological applications in categories such as gas storage, selective molecular adsorption, separations, ion exchange, catalysis, magnetic and photoluminescence responses, optoelectronics, and drug delivery. Some of the hybrid organic-inorganic porous frameworks demonstrate significant structural flexibility in response to changes, in guest concentration, pressure, or temperature with retention of single crystallinity. Examples include the MX(bdc) compounds first reported by Férey et al., which are based on chains of trans corner-sharing MX2O4 (M = V, Cr, Al, Fe, In, Ga, Mn, Sc, and X = O, OH, F) octahedra cross-linked by 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc). The three-dimensional framework that results consists of one-dimensional rhombic channels. The first member of the group [VIII(OH)(bdc)](H2bdc) x , known as MIL-47as, loses the guest acid on heating in air and at the same time the framework V3+ ions are oxidized to V4+ forming [VIVO(bdc)] or MIL-47, without changing the topology of the framework, thus providing the first evidence of chemically induced redox reactions within this system. One particular feature of [VIVO(bdc)], MIL-47, is its lack of affinity for water. As a result, by removing H2bdc guest molecules, the empty framework is obtained which is stable under ambient conditions. A second example of a redox reaction was reported by Férey et al., who investigated the electrochemical reactivity of [FeIII(OH)0.8F0.2(bdc)](H2O) [MIL-53(Fe)] with lithium. Lithium ions can be repeatedly intercalated/deintercalated into/from the channels, accompanied by reduction/oxidation of Fe3+ and Fe2+.

elements.content: One of the interesting features of MOFs is the potential to control the chemical nature of the pores through postsynthetic modification, whereby a preformed MOF undergoes further reaction. One way to fine-tune the physical and chemical properties of MOFs is to incorporate functional guest molecules inside the pores of the network. As mentioned above, the [VIVO(bdc)] framework can be completely evacuated at ambient atmosphere due to the absence of bridging −OH group. Once the channels are empty, other species may be reversibly intercalated.

One way to fine-tune the physical and chemical properties of MOFs is to incorporate functional guest molecules inside the pores of the network. As mentioned above, the [VIVO(bdc)] framework can be completely evacuated at ambient atmosphere due to the absence of bridging -OH group. Once the channels are empty, other species may be reversibly intercalated.

elements.content: Among the numerous properties of porous organic–inorganic frameworks, the redox and electrical properties have received relatively limited attention. MOFs still face a number of challenges in this area, particularly with regard to their insulating nature. The incorporation of redox active guest molecules represents one strategy toward improving the charge transport properties of the materials. Enhanced electronic conductivity of MOFs which exhibit redox active frameworks and show charge-transfer between the framework and the adsorbed molecules may open new perspectives, such as the use of MOFs as porous electrodes for lithium-ion batteries, fuel cells, and capacitors, and as active molds for the preparation of metallic nanoparticles, as well as in the areas of solid-state sensing and electrocatalysis.

elements.content: Hydroquinone (H2Q), or benzene-1,4-diol, is well-known as key building block in many biological proton–electron transfer (PET) reactions. In particular, hydroquinone can reversibly undergo a 2é, 2H+ transfer to give p-benzoquinone (Q): H2Q → Q + 2H+ + 2é. Hydroquinone/p-benzoquinone system is perhaps the most well-studied and considered as the classical organic redox reaction. This motivated us to investigate the intercalation of the redox active guest hydroquinone into the [VIVO(bdc)] host framework.

In particular, hydroquinone can reversibly undergo a 2é, 2H+ transfer to give p-benzoquinone (Q): H2Q → Q + 2H+ + 2é. Hydroquinone/p-benzoquinone system is perhaps the most well-studied and considered as the classical organic redox reaction. This motivated us to investigate the intercalation of the redox active guest hydroquinone into the [VIVO(bdc)] host framework.

elements.content: All chemicals used during this work were reagent grade and used as received from commercial sources without further purification. Infrared (IR) measurements were carried out on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer in the range 400–4000 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements were carried out using a TA Instruments Hi-Res 2950 system with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. Elemental analyses were performed by Galbraith Laboratories (Knoxville, TN). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected at room temperature on a Phillips PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54046 Å). X-band EPR measurements were performed on a Bruker BioSpin instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All chemicals used during this work were reagent grade and used as received from commercial sources without further purification. Infrared (IR) measurements were carried out on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR spectrometer in the range 400-4000 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements were carried out using a TA Instruments Hi-Res 2950 system with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. Elemental analyses were performed by Galbraith Laboratories (Knoxville, TN). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected at room temperature on a Phillips PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54046 Å). X-band EPR measurements were performed on a Bruker BioSpin instrument.

elements.content: Compound 1 was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction as previously reported. A reaction mixture of VO2, HCl, H2bdc, and H2O (molar ratio = 1:2:0.5:77) was heated in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel autoclave at 220 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Red brown prisms of 1 were recovered as a major phase by vacuum filtration and drying in air, together with a minor dark green impurity, which was easily removed by washing with methanol.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7 (1)

Compound 1 was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction as previously reported. A reaction mixture of VO2, HCl, H2bdc, and H2O (molar ratio = 1:2:0.5:77) was heated in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel autoclave at 220 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Red brown prisms of 1 were recovered as a major phase by vacuum filtration and drying in air, together with a minor dark green impurity, which was easily removed by washing with methanol.

elements.content: To obtain [VIVO(bdc)] (2), red crystals of 1 were heated at 380 °C for 4 h in air to remove H2bdc from the channels. After cooling to room temperature, the crystals were transferred to a quartz tube, evacuated to a pressure less than 10–2 mTorr, and heated to 350 °C for 2 h under vacuum to sublime any remaining H2bdc.
elements.clean_text:
Activation of [VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7 (1)

To obtain [VIVO(bdc)] (2), red crystals of 1 were heated at 380 °C for 4 h in air to remove H2bdc from the channels. After cooling to room temperature, the crystals were transferred to a quartz tube, evacuated to a pressure less than 10-2 mTorr, and heated to 350 °C for 2 h under vacuum to sublime any remaining H2bdc.

elements.content:
Hydroquinone (H2Q) was intercalated into [VIVO(bdc)] by two different methods as follows:

Ambient Air Method

The activated crystals of 2 were placed together with hydroquinone in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel autoclave in separate small glass vessels with the molar ratio 2:H2Q = 1:47 in air. The autoclave was heated to 220 °C for 24 h and then cooled to room temperature. The dark red crystals of 2 turned black after the intercalation. The final product was determined to be [VIII(OH)(bdc)]·{(O–C6H4–O)(HO-C6H4–OH)}0.38·(H2O)0.48 (3). Anal. Calcd: V, 15.74; C, 46.60; H, 3.04. Found: V, 15.30; C, 47.11; H, 3.27 wt %.
elements.clean_text:
Redox Intercalation of Hydroquinone

Hydroquinone (H2Q) was intercalated into [VIVO(bdc)] by two different methods as follows:

Ambient Air Method

The activated crystals of 2 were placed together with hydroquinone in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel autoclave in separate small glass vessels with the molar ratio 2:H2Q = 1:47 in air. The autoclave was heated to 220 °C for 24 h and then cooled to room temperature. The dark red crystals of 2 turned black after the intercalation. The final product was determined to be [VIII(OH)(bdc)]⋅{(O-C6H4-O)(HO-C6H4-OH)}0.38⋅(H2O)0.48 (3). Anal. Calcd: V, 15.74; C, 46.60; H, 3.04. Found: V, 15.30; C, 47.11; H, 3.27 wt %.

elements.content: The reactants were loaded inside an argon-filled glovebox and all manipulations were carried out under an inert atmosphere. The activated crystals of 2 and hydroquinone with the molar ratio 2:H2Q = 1:47 were used. Hydroquinone which had been dried in vacuum at 110 °C overnight was placed on the bottom of a quartz tube. Crystals of 2 were wrapped in gold mesh and suspended above hydroquinone using a gold wire. The quartz tube was then evacuated to a pressure less than 10–2 mTorr at room temperature overnight before it was sealed under vacuum. The tube was heated to 150 °C at 10 °C/min and subsequently heated to 290 °C with a heating rate of 1 °C/min, and held at 290 °C for 30 min. The dark red crystals of 2 turned black after the intercalation. The final product was determined to be [VIII(O–C6H4–O)(bdc)] (4). Anal. Calcd: V, 15.76; C, 52.04; H, 2.50. Found: V, 14.99; C, 52.84; H, 2.83 wt %.
elements.clean_text:
Anhydrous Atmosphere Method

The reactants were loaded inside an argon-filled glovebox and all manipulations were carried out under an inert atmosphere. The activated crystals of 2 and hydroquinone with the molar ratio 2:H2Q = 1:47 were used. Hydroquinone which had been dried in vacuum at 110 °C overnight was placed on the bottom of a quartz tube. Crystals of 2 were wrapped in gold mesh and suspended above hydroquinone using a gold wire. The quartz tube was then evacuated to a pressure less than 10-2 mTorr at room temperature overnight before it was sealed under vacuum. The tube was heated to 150 °C at 10 °C/min and subsequently heated to 290 °C with a heating rate of 1 °C/min, and held at 290 °C for 30 min. The dark red crystals of 2 turned black after the intercalation. The final product was determined to be [VIII(O-C6H4-O)(bdc)] (4). Anal. Calcd: V, 15.76; C, 52.04; H, 2.50. Found: V, 14.99; C, 52.84; H, 2.83 wt %.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analyses were performed at room temperature on a Siemens SMART platform diffractometer outfitted with an APEX II area detector and monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined using Bruker Apex2 software package. The hydrogen atoms of the organic species were located geometrically and refined isotropically with position and displacement parameters riding on the non-hydrogen atoms to which they are bonded. Hydrogen atoms of the disordered water molecules were not located. A number of crystals of 4 were checked and were all found to be twins. Intensity data measured on a twinned crystal of 4 were corrected with the program TWINABS and used for structure determination. Crystallographic data and structure refinements for compounds 3 and 4 are summarized in . More details on the crystallographic studies are given in the CIF files.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray analyses were performed at room temperature on a Siemens SMART platform diffractometer outfitted with an APEX II area detector and monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined using Bruker Apex2 software package. The hydrogen atoms of the organic species were located geometrically and refined isotropically with position and displacement parameters riding on the non-hydrogen atoms to which they are bonded. Hydrogen atoms of the disordered water molecules were not located. A number of crystals of 4 were checked and were all found to be twins. Intensity data measured on a twinned crystal of 4 were corrected with the program TWINABS and used for structure determination. Crystallographic data and structure refinements for compounds 3 and 4 are summarized in . More details on the crystallographic studies are given in the CIF files.

elements.content: [VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7 (1) can be prepared by the hydrothermal method previously described. To remove the large amount of H2bdc guest species from the channels, the activation of 1 is done in two steps. The red crystals of 1 are first heated in air at 380 °C to remove the majority of H2bdc. After cooling to room temperature, the crystals are transferred to a quartz tube, evacuated to a pressure less than 10–2 mTorr, and heated again to 350 °C under vacuum to sublime any remaining H2bdc. A very small amount of white H2bdc solid appears on the cold part of the tube and the tube is sealed in the middle to separate [VIVO(bdc)] (2) from the last trace of H2bdc. This is done to ensure the completeness of framework activation. It was found that the quality of the activated crystals is highly dependent on the heating rate during the activation. As reported previously, the unit cell dimensions change as H2bdc guest molecules are removed from the structure: [VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7 (1) [substructure], P212121, a = 6.8094(3), b = 12.4220(6), c = 17.1733(8) Å, V = 1452.6(1) Å3 and [VIVO(bdc)] (2), Pnma, a = 6.8249(8), b = 16.073(2), c = 13.995(2) Å, V = 1535.2(3) Å3. These changes during the framework activation lead to cracks in the single crystals of 2. As a result, the lower the heating rate, the better the quality of the activated crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

[VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7 (1) can be prepared by the hydrothermal method previously described. To remove the large amount of H2bdc guest species from the channels, the activation of 1 is done in two steps. The red crystals of 1 are first heated in air at 380 °C to remove the majority of H2bdc. After cooling to room temperature, the crystals are transferred to a quartz tube, evacuated to a pressure less than 10-2 mTorr, and heated again to 350 °C under vacuum to sublime any remaining H2bdc. A very small amount of white H2bdc solid appears on the cold part of the tube and the tube is sealed in the middle to separate [VIVO(bdc)] (2) from the last trace of H2bdc. This is done to ensure the completeness of framework activation. It was found that the quality of the activated crystals is highly dependent on the heating rate during the activation. As reported previously, the unit cell dimensions change as H2bdc guest molecules are removed from the structure: [VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7 (1) [substructure], P212121, a = 6.8094(3), b = 12.4220(6), c = 17.1733(8) Å, V = 1452.6(1) Å3 and [VIVO(bdc)] (2), Pnma, a = 6.8249(8), b = 16.073(2), c = 13.995(2) Å, V = 1535.2(3) Å3. These changes during the framework activation lead to cracks in the single crystals of 2. As a result, the lower the heating rate, the better the quality of the activated crystals.

elements.content: Once the empty framework of 2 is obtained, hydroquinone (H2Q) is used as guest for redox intercalation by two different methods: in ambient air and under anhydrous conditions. When [VIVO(bdc)] (2) and hydroquinone are loaded in air, moisture from air is an important factor that drives the intercalation toward the product [VIII(OH)(bdc)]·{(O–C6H4–O)(HO-C6H4–OH)}0.38·(H2O)0.48 (3). As hydroquinone molecules are inserted into [VIVO(bdc)] framework in the presence of water, quinhydrone which is a well-known charge-transfer complex between hydroquinone (H2Q) and p-benzoquinone (Q), is formed inside the channels and simultaneously V4+ ions are reduced to V3+; a small amount of water is also present. Under anhydrous conditions, hydroquinone molecules are found to functionalize the [VIVO(bdc)] framework itself, as V4+ ions are reduced to V3+ to form [VIII(O–C6H4–O)(bdc)] (4). In both methods (in ambient air and under anhydrous atmosphere), the transformations take place via a single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion (single crystals of 2 to 3, and 2 to 4, respectively).

As hydroquinone molecules are inserted into [VIVO(bdc)] framework in the presence of water, quinhydrone which is a well-known charge-transfer complex between hydroquinone (H2Q) and p-benzoquinone (Q), is formed inside the channels and simultaneously V4+ ions are reduced to V3+; a small amount of water is also present. Under anhydrous conditions, hydroquinone molecules are found to functionalize the [VIVO(bdc)] framework itself, as V4+ ions are reduced to V3+ to form [VIII(O-C6H4-O)(bdc)] (4). In both methods (in ambient air and under anhydrous atmosphere), the transformations take place via a single-crystal-to-single-crystal fashion (single crystals of 2 to 3, and 2 to 4, respectively).

elements.content: The structure of 2 has been described previously. Chains of trans corner-sharing VO6 octahedra (Figure a), which are cross-linked by 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) are shown in Figure b. The octahedral chains have a −OV–OV– backbone with alternating short (1.612(1) Å) and long (2.189(2) Å) V–O apical bonds of the VO6 octahedra, typical for vanadium ions in tetravalent oxidation state, and a V–O–V angle of 128.7°. The equatorial corners of the VO6 octahedra are shared with the bdc ligands. The one-dimensional channels parallel to the octahedral chains have a diamond-shaped cross-section with an aperture of ∼7.6 × 7.7 Å (Figure c). The structure has a space group symmetry of Pnma with the octahedral chains parallel to the a-axis and the (010) plane running through the zigzag −OV–OV– backbone. The bdc ligands are flat with their benzene ring plane almost parallel to the channel axis. The angle between the bdc benzene ring and the channel axis is only 3.7°. This small inclination of bdc toward the channel axis causes a slight fluctuation of the channel aperture along the channel axis and makes the individual channels polar. However, the polarities of neighboring channels are in opposite directions, causing the structure as a whole to be nonpolar.
elements.clean_text:
Porous Structure of [VIVO(bdc)] (2)

The structure of 2 has been described previously. Chains of trans corner-sharing VO6 octahedra (Figure a), which are cross-linked by 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) are shown in Figure b. The octahedral chains have a -OV-OV- backbone with alternating short (1.612(1) Å) and long (2.189(2) Å) V-O apical bonds of the VO6 octahedra, typical for vanadium ions in tetravalent oxidation state, and a V-O-V angle of 128.7°. The equatorial corners of the VO6 octahedra are shared with the bdc ligands. The one-dimensional channels parallel to the octahedral chains have a diamond-shaped cross-section with an aperture of ~7.6 × 7.7 Å (Figure c). The structure has a space group symmetry of Pnma with the octahedral chains parallel to the a-axis and the (010) plane running through the zigzag -OV-OV- backbone. The bdc ligands are flat with their benzene ring plane almost parallel to the channel axis. The angle between the bdc benzene ring and the channel axis is only 3.7°. This small inclination of bdc toward the channel axis causes a slight fluctuation of the channel aperture along the channel axis and makes the individual channels polar. However, the polarities of neighboring channels are in opposite directions, causing the structure as a whole to be nonpolar.

elements.content: During redox intercalation in the presence of air at 220 °C under autogenous pressure, some of the hydroquinone (H2Q) (Figure a) first undergoes oxidation to form p-benzoquinone (Q) in a two-electron process: H2Q → Q + 2H+ + 2e–. Once p-benzoquinone (Q) is produced, it can combine with the excess hydroquinone to form the quinhydrone complex (Figure b). Simultaneously, V4+ ions in the [VIVO(bdc)] framework (2) are reduced by the electrons generated to V3+ and the protons attach to the bridging oxygen atom; thus, μ2-oxo becomes μ2–OH.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [VIII(OH)(bdc)]⋅{(O-C6H4-O)(HO-C6H4-OH)}0.38⋅(H2O)0.48 (3)

During redox intercalation in the presence of air at 220 °C under autogenous pressure, some of the hydroquinone (H2Q) (Figure a) first undergoes oxidation to form p-benzoquinone (Q) in a two-electron process: H2Q → Q + 2H+ + 2e-. Once p-benzoquinone (Q) is produced, it can combine with the excess hydroquinone to form the quinhydrone complex (Figure b). Simultaneously, V4+ ions in the [VIVO(bdc)] framework (2) are reduced by the electrons generated to V3+ and the protons attach to the bridging oxygen atom; thus, μ2-oxo becomes μ2-OH.

elements.content: The three-dimensional structure of 3 is illustrated in Figure . The host framework is closely similar to that of the previously reported MIL-47as, which is based on VIII, but the unit cell is doubled along the channel axis because of ordering of the guest quinhydrone species. The six V–O distances in 3 lie in the range of 1.938(1)···2.011(2) Å, which is typical for VIII–O bonds. The vanadium oxygen octahedron is slightly compressed with axial V–O bond lengths of 1.938(1) and 1.940(1) Å, and equatorial V–O bond lengths of 2.002(2)···2.011(2) Å. The two nonequivalent axial oxygen atoms are shared by neighboring octahedra to form a zigzag ···OH–V–OH–V–··· backbone with alternating V–OH–V angles of 124.7 and 124.4°. The equatorial oxygen atoms are shared with the dicarboxylate anions that cross-link the octahedral chains into a 3D framework. The bond valence sum calculated for the V ion is 3.13 v.u. in agreement with the V3+ assignment. Reduction of V(IV) to V(III) is expected to increase the framework flexibility as discussed by LeClerc et al. for MIL-47. Unlike MIL-47(VIV), which has an open-pore structure and lacks affinity for water, MIL-47(VIII) breathes like MIL-53 and adopts a narrow pore hydrated form with monoclinic C2/c symmetry in ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text: The three-dimensional structure of 3 is illustrated in Figure . The host framework is closely similar to that of the previously reported MIL-47as, which is based on VIII, but the unit cell is doubled along the channel axis because of ordering of the guest quinhydrone species. The six V-O distances in 3 lie in the range of 1.938(1)⋅⋅⋅2.011(2) Å, which is typical for VIII-O bonds. The vanadium oxygen octahedron is slightly compressed with axial V-O bond lengths of 1.938(1) and 1.940(1) Å, and equatorial V-O bond lengths of 2.002(2)⋅⋅⋅2.011(2) Å. The two nonequivalent axial oxygen atoms are shared by neighboring octahedra to form a zigzag ⋅⋅⋅OH-V-OH-V-⋅⋅⋅ backbone with alternating V-OH-V angles of 124.7 and 124.4°. The equatorial oxygen atoms are shared with the dicarboxylate anions that cross-link the octahedral chains into a 3D framework. The bond valence sum calculated for the V ion is 3.13 v.u. in agreement with the V3+ assignment. Reduction of V(IV) to V(III) is expected to increase the framework flexibility as discussed by LeClerc et al. for MIL-47. Unlike MIL-47(VIV), which has an open-pore structure and lacks affinity for water, MIL-47(VIII) breathes like MIL-53 and adopts a narrow pore hydrated form with monoclinic C2/c symmetry in ambient conditions.

elements.content: The rhombic-shaped channels of the framework of 3 are filled with guest quinhydrone complexes. Intercalated into the empty channels of 2 in the vapor phase, the quinhydrone complex, composed of equimolar p-benzoquinone (Q) and hydroquinone (H2Q), is held together by π–π charge-transfer interactions. The electron-withdrawing carbonyl groups on p-benzoquinone make the aromatic ring relatively poor in π electron density; as a result, p-benzoquinone behaves as an electron acceptor. On the other hand, the electron-donating hydroxyl groups on hydroquinone make the aromatic ring relatively electron rich, and make hydroquinone a good electron donor. In each quinhydrone complex, the p-benzoquinone molecules are randomly disordered over two positions with the same orientation but shifted laterally by 0.89 Å from each other roughly along [110]. This leads to half of p-benzoquinone molecules having a much shorter π–π stacking distance, measured between the C6 ring centers, to the hydroquinone molecule (3.64 Å) and longer π–π stacking distance to the framework bdc ligand (3.73 Å), compared to the other half of Q molecules (4.03 Å to H2Q and 3.64 Å to bdc). No π–π interactions between the H2Q molecules and framework bdc are present (stacking distance 4.99 Å).

elements.content: The intercalated quinhydrone complexes form a column in each channel with neighboring complexes rotated by 70.3° relative to each other, along the channel axis as shown in Figure . The quinhydrone molecules in neighboring channels are oriented almost perpendicular to one another. The guest quinhydrone complexes in 3 lie parallel to the channel axis and the bdc ligands of the framework, which maximizes packing efficiency and facilitates π–π interactions with the framework bdc molecules. This pattern allows all columns of guest molecules to have favorable π–π interactions with the framework bdc linkers. The primary π–π interaction between the quinhydrone and the framework bdc molecule seems to play a major role in dictating the quinhydrone orientation.

elements.content: The packing of the intercalated quinhydrone complex in 3 differs from that found in the triclinic and monoclinic forms of quinhydrone previously reported. In the intercalation compound 3, adjacent pairs of hydroquinone and p-benzoquinone are rotated by 70.3°, whereas in triclinic and monoclinic structures, the adjacent pairs of molecules are located on the same plane forming flat sheets of infinite hydrogen bonded quinhydrone complexes (with π–π stacking distance of 3.221 Å and hydrogen bonding distance OH···O between adjacent hydroquinone and p-benzoquinone molecules of 2.739 and 2.738 Å for the triclinic and monoclinic structures, respectively). In the triclinic and monoclinic modifications, both the π–π charge-transfer between the electron donor (hydroquinone) and the electron acceptor (p-benzoquinone) and the hydrogen bonds stabilize the complex.

elements.content: The occupancy of the quinhydrone complex was refined to approximately 0.76 in good agreement with the elemental analysis and TGA results. In addition to the intercalated quinhydrone, water molecules were also located in the channels of 3. Each water molecule is weakly hydrogen bonded to an μ2–OH group of the octahedral chain and −CO of p-benzoquinone with the O···O distance of 3.07(2) and 3.03(4) Å, respectively. Upon intercalation of the guest molecules, the tunnel openings in [VO(bdc)] systematically shrink because of the interactions between the guest molecules and the host framework. This behavior is illustrated by the ratio of the two diagonals of the tunnel section, which changes from 14.00:16.07 (0.87) in 2 to 12.60:17.29 (0.73) in 3. The deformations are realized mainly through changes of the torsion angle V–OC–C, which is the most flexible component of the framework.

elements.content: When [VIVO(bdc)] (2) and hydroquinone are heated together at 290 °C in a sealed tube under vacuum, hydroquinone (H2Q) first thermally decomposes via the formation of a resonance stabilized p-semiquinone radical and p-semiquinone radical anion, to yield p-benzoquinone (Q) as the dominant product as described in Scheme . As reported by Dellinger and co-workers, the thermal degradation of hydroquinone initiates at 250 °C and p-benzoquinone is the only observable product below 700 °C. This strongly suggests the formation of p-semiquinone radical as an intermediate.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [VIII(O-C6H4-O)(bdc)] (4)

When [VIVO(bdc)] (2) and hydroquinone are heated together at 290 °C in a sealed tube under vacuum, hydroquinone (H2Q) first thermally decomposes via the formation of a resonance stabilized p-semiquinone radical and p-semiquinone radical anion, to yield p-benzoquinone (Q) as the dominant product as described in Scheme . As reported by Dellinger and co-workers, the thermal degradation of hydroquinone initiates at 250 °C and p-benzoquinone is the only observable product below 700 °C. This strongly suggests the formation of p-semiquinone radical as an intermediate.

elements.clean_text: 1  Formation of p-Semiquinone Radical and p-Benzoquinone from the Pyrolysis of Hydroquinone

elements.content: During the first step of the thermal decomposition, one electron (e–) and one proton (H+) are given off, as hydroquinone (H2Q) becomes the p-semiquinone radical. This electron then reduces V4+ ion in the [VIV(O)(bdc)] framework (2) to V3+, and the proton simultaneously protonates the bridging oxygen μ2-oxo to become μ2–OH. As the p-semiquinone radical further transforms into p-semiquinone radical anion, it gives off one more proton (H+), which then protonates the μ2–OH. The p-semiquinone radical anion is believed to be the species responsible for functionalizing the vanadium octahedral chain. As the p-semiquinone radical anion attacks the vanadium chain, a water molecule departs the chain. This functionalization of the chains by the p-semiquinone radical anion takes place throughout the structure, until all the bridging μ2-oxygen atoms are replaced by p-semiquinone radical anions and all of the V4+ ions are reduced to V3+ ions as shown in Figure .

elements.content: The C–O bond protruding into the channel that is part of −O(C6H4O) has a bond length of 1.24(8) Å (after correction for libration) corresponding to a bond order less than 2, which is in agreement with the known resonance and conjugation effect for a semiquinone radical. The unpaired electron delocalizes throughout the benzene ring as indicated by a g-value determined by EPR spectroscopy that is less than 2.003 with a broad spectrum (), suggesting a carbon-centered radical. The other C–O bond of −O(C6H4O) which connects two vanadium atoms together has a bond length of 1.43(2) Å and is longer than the other C–O bond previously described. (It is noteworthy that the C–OH bond distance in hydroquinone is 1.38 Å.) This is probably caused by the steric effect between the aromatic ring and the vanadium octahedral chain.

elements.content: TGA measurement of 3 performed from room temperature to 600 °C at 2 °C/min in N2 flow shows a thermal decomposition in three steps between 80 and 450 °C (). The first two steps correspond to the removal of water molecules in the channels (∼100 °C, 2.67% calculated) and all the quinhydrone complexes (∼180–320 °C, 25.62% calculated), respectively. The plateau at the end of the second step corresponds to 72.05% measured, 71.71% calculated. The third weight loss between 340 and 450 °C corresponds to the loss of the framework bdc molecules (50.34% measured, 50.71% calculated). The residue was confirmed by PXRD to be V2O3. Elemental analysis of 3 also gives a quinhydrone content of 0.38 per formula unit, in accordance with the X-ray data refinement. TGA measurement of 4 performed from room temperature to 950 °C at 2 °C/min in N2 flow shows no clear thermal decomposition step (). The weight loss occurs over the whole temperature range relating to the combustion of the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

TGA measurement of 3 performed from room temperature to 600 °C at 2 °C/min in N2 flow shows a thermal decomposition in three steps between 80 and 450 °C (). The first two steps correspond to the removal of water molecules in the channels (~100 °C, 2.67% calculated) and all the quinhydrone complexes (~180-320 °C, 25.62% calculated), respectively. The plateau at the end of the second step corresponds to 72.05% measured, 71.71% calculated. The third weight loss between 340 and 450 °C corresponds to the loss of the framework bdc molecules (50.34% measured, 50.71% calculated). The residue was confirmed by PXRD to be V2O3. Elemental analysis of 3 also gives a quinhydrone content of 0.38 per formula unit, in accordance with the X-ray data refinement. TGA measurement of 4 performed from room temperature to 950 °C at 2 °C/min in N2 flow shows no clear thermal decomposition step (). The weight loss occurs over the whole temperature range relating to the combustion of the framework.

elements.content: The infrared spectrum of compound 3 () shows the vibrational bands characteristic of the framework −(O–C–O)– groups around 1550 and 1430 cm–1, confirming the presence of the dicarboxylate within the solid; a band at ca. 1700 cm–1 characteristic of free −CO groups (as part of the quinhydrone) is also observed for compound 3 but not for compound 2 (, shown in comparison with the spectrum of 1, ), which is in agreement with the absence of free H2bdc acid within the pores for this solid. The observed vibrational bands of 3 at 1632 cm–1 and in the region 3600–3500 cm–1 correspond to the bending and stretching modes of water, respectively. They also overlap with the signature of the hydroxyl group μ2–OH bridging the vanadium atoms, and the hydroxyl group which is part of the quinhydrone complex, in comparison with the absence of bands in the same region for compound 2. The infrared spectrum of compound 4 () is quite similar, except for the absence of bands around 3500 cm–1, suggesting that the bridging species is −O–C6H4–O and confirming the absence of OH group in the structure. Powder XRD data of the compounds are displayed in . In general, the peak positions on the experimental PXRD patterns are in very good agreement with the simulated patterns. No extra lines are present, indicating the purity of the bulk products.

The observed vibrational bands of 3 at 1632 cm-1 and in the region 3600-3500 cm-1 correspond to the bending and stretching modes of water, respectively. They also overlap with the signature of the hydroxyl group μ2-OH bridging the vanadium atoms, and the hydroxyl group which is part of the quinhydrone complex, in comparison with the absence of bands in the same region for compound 2. elements.content: We describe an example of redox intercalation using vanadium benzenedicarboxylate, [VIVO(bdc)] conventionally denoted as MIL-47, as the host and electroactive hydroquinone as the guest. The single crystals of the as-synthesized [VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7, 1, were heated in air to remove the guest acid molecules. The resulting [VIVO(bdc)] structure, 2, was sufficiently flexible and stable to undergo redox intercalation with hydroquinone. The reaction temperatures and especially the atmosphere were found to be the primary factors that determined the products. In ambient atmosphere, when 2 was heated together with hydroquinone, a quinhydrone charge- transfer complex formed inside the channels and V4+ ions were reduced to V3+ to yield compound 3. Under anhydrous conditions, the [VIVO(bdc)] framework (2) was found to be functionalized by hydroquinone. According to EPR studies, the product from the anhydrous reaction (4) contains unpaired electrons, and the p-semiquinone radical anion is believed to be the species responsible, with the reduction of V4+ to V3+. The incorporated redox active guest species and reduction of the inorganic chain may lead to interesting electrical properties. In preliminary work, the complex permittivity of a submillimeter size single crystal of [V(O)bdc](H2bdc)0.71 was characterized at 12 GHz using a scanning-sample split-post dielectric resonator technique. Resonant frequency and quality-factor Q changes introduced by the crystal interaction with the microwave fields were measured and cavity perturbation theory was used to calculate the complex permittivity. The effective permittivity of the crystal was found to be anisotropic. The details of the meaurement technique and the anlysis of the data are beyond the scope of this paper and will be reported in detail elsewhere.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We describe an example of redox intercalation using vanadium benzenedicarboxylate, [VIVO(bdc)] conventionally denoted as MIL-47, as the host and electroactive hydroquinone as the guest. The single crystals of the as-synthesized [VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7, 1, were heated in air to remove the guest acid molecules. The resulting [VIVO(bdc)] structure, 2, was sufficiently flexible and stable to undergo redox intercalation with hydroquinone. The reaction temperatures and especially the atmosphere were found to be the primary factors that determined the products. In ambient atmosphere, when 2 was heated together with hydroquinone, a quinhydrone charge- transfer complex formed inside the channels and V4+ ions were reduced to V3+ to yield compound 3. Under anhydrous conditions, the [VIVO(bdc)] framework (2) was found to be functionalized by hydroquinone. According to EPR studies, the product from the anhydrous reaction (4) contains unpaired electrons, and the p-semiquinone radical anion is believed to be the species responsible, with the reduction of V4+ to V3+. The incorporated redox active guest species and reduction of the inorganic chain may lead to interesting electrical properties. In preliminary work, the complex permittivity of a submillimeter size single crystal of [V(O)bdc](H2bdc)0.71 was characterized at 12 GHz using a scanning-sample split-post dielectric resonator technique. Resonant frequency and quality-factor Q changes introduced by the crystal interaction with the microwave fields were measured and cavity perturbation theory was used to calculate the complex permittivity. The effective permittivity of the crystal was found to be anisotropic. The details of the meaurement technique and the anlysis of the data are beyond the scope of this paper and will be reported in detail elsewhere.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction as previously reported. A reaction mixture of VO2, HCl, H2bdc, and H2O (molar ratio = 1:2:0.5:77) was heated in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel autoclave at 220 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Red brown prisms of 1 were recovered as a major phase by vacuum filtration and drying in air, together with a minor dark green impurity, which was easily removed by washing with methanol.

Activation of [V<sup>IV</sup>O(bdc)](H<sub>2</sub>bdc)<sub>5/7</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

To obtain [VIVO(bdc)] (2), red crystals of 1 were heated at 380 °C for 4 h in air to remove H2bdc from the channels. After cooling to room temperature, the crystals were transferred to a quartz tube, evacuated to a pressure less than 10–2 mTorr, and heated to 350 °C for 2 h under vacuum to sublime any remaining H2bdc.

Redox Intercalation of Hydroquinone

Hydroquinone (H2Q) was intercalated into [VIVO(bdc)] by two different methods as follows:

Ambient Air Method

The activated crystals of 2 were placed together with hydroquinone in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel autoclave in separate small glass vessels with the molar ratio 2:H2Q = 1:47 in air. The autoclave was heated to 220 °C for 24 h and then cooled to room temperature. The dark red crystals of 2 turned black after the intercalation. The final product was determined to be [VIII(OH)(bdc)]·{(O–C6H4–O)(HO-C6H4–OH)}0.38·(H2O)0.48 (3). Anal. Calcd: V, 15.74; C, 46.60; H, 3.04. Found: V, 15.30; C, 47.11; H, 3.27 wt %.

Synthesis of [VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7 (1)

Compound 1 was synthesized by hydrothermal reaction as previously reported. A reaction mixture of VO2, HCl, H2bdc, and H2O (molar ratio = 1:2:0.5:77) was heated in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel autoclave at 220 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. Red brown prisms of 1 were recovered as a major phase by vacuum filtration and drying in air, together with a minor dark green impurity, which was easily removed by washing with methanol.

Activation of [VIVO(bdc)](H2bdc)5/7 (1)

To obtain [VIVO(bdc)] (2), red crystals of 1 were heated at 380 °C for 4 h in air to remove H2bdc from the channels. After cooling to room temperature, the crystals were transferred to a quartz tube, evacuated to a pressure less than 10-2 mTorr, and heated to 350 °C for 2 h under vacuum to sublime any remaining H2bdc.

Hydroquinone (H2Q) was intercalated into [VIVO(bdc)] by two different methods as follows:

Ambient Air Method

The activated crystals of 2 were placed together with hydroquinone in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr stainless steel autoclave in separate small glass vessels with the molar ratio 2:H2Q = 1:47 in air. The autoclave was heated to 220 °C for 24 h and then cooled to room temperature. The dark red crystals of 2 turned black after the intercalation. The final product was determined to be [VIII(OH)(bdc)]⋅{(O-C6H4-O)(HO-C6H4-OH)}0.38⋅(H2O)0.48 (3). Anal. Calcd: V, 15.74; C, 46.60; H, 3.04. Found: V, 15.30; C, 47.11; H, 3.27 wt %.

cln_elements.content: TGA measurement of 3 performed from room temperature to 600 °C at 2 °C/min in N2 flow shows a thermal decomposition in three steps between 80 and 450 °C (). The first two steps correspond to the removal of water molecules in the channels (∼100 °C, 2.67% calculated) and all the quinhydrone complexes (∼180–320 °C, 25.62% calculated), respectively. The plateau at the end of the second step corresponds to 72.05% measured, 71.71% calculated. The third weight loss between 340 and 450 °C corresponds to the loss of the framework bdc molecules (50.34% measured, 50.71% calculated). The residue was confirmed by PXRD to be V2O3. Elemental analysis of 3 also gives a quinhydrone content of 0.38 per formula unit, in accordance with the X-ray data refinement. TGA measurement of 4 performed from room temperature to 950 °C at 2 °C/min in N2 flow shows no clear thermal decomposition step (). The weight loss occurs over the whole temperature range relating to the combustion of the framework.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

TGA measurement of 3 performed from room temperature to 600 °C at 2 °C/min in N2 flow shows a thermal decomposition in three steps between 80 and 450 °C (). The first two steps correspond to the removal of water molecules in the channels (~100 °C, 2.67% calculated) and all the quinhydrone complexes (~180-320 °C, 25.62% calculated), respectively. The plateau at the end of the second step corresponds to 72.05% measured, 71.71% calculated. The third weight loss between 340 and 450 °C corresponds to the loss of the framework bdc molecules (50.34% measured, 50.71% calculated). The residue was confirmed by PXRD to be V2O3. Elemental analysis of 3 also gives a quinhydrone content of 0.38 per formula unit, in accordance with the X-ray data refinement. TGA measurement of 4 performed from room temperature to 950 °C at 2 °C/min in N2 flow shows no clear thermal decomposition step (). The weight loss occurs over the whole temperature range relating to the combustion of the framework.
